title: Samuel L Jackson attacks Martin Scorsese for comments about Marvel
text:
Martin Scorsese stirred up controversy over comments that Marvel films are 'not cinema' and even compared them to theme parks.

And as Samuel L. Jackson is the man who brought the Avengers together in film and the highest-grossing actor of all time, there is no better representative to defend the mega-franchise.

The 70-year-old actor fired back at the 76-year-old filmmaker in an interview with Variety over the weekend as he lead the fellow thespians who have also starred in the Marvel Cinematic Universe who responded to the Goodfellas director's criticism.

Taking aim: Samuel L. Jackson - pictured at the grand opening gala at Tyler Perry studios on Saturday - fired back at comments made by Martin Scorsese about the Marvel Cinematic Universe

'Not cinema': The 76-year-old filmmaker (pictured in New York last month) stirred up controversy as he made compared comic book films to 'theme parks' in an interview with Empire Magazine

Jackson - who has starred as Nick Fury in 13 films - told the weekly: 'I mean that’s like saying Bugs Bunny ain’t funny. Films are films. Everybody doesn’t like his stuff either.

'Everybody’s got an opinion, so I mean it’s okay. Ain’t going to stop nobody from making movies.'

The debate began last week after Scorsese made the comments about the comic book films to Empire Magazine as he said: 'I don’t see them. I tried, you know? But that’s not cinema.

'Everybody doesn’t like his stuff either': The 70-year-old actor took a stern stance in an interview with Variety as he has starred as Nick Fury in 13 films

Samuel L. Jackson responds to Martin Scorsese’s Marvel comments: “I mean that’s like saying Bugs Bunny ain’t funny. Films are films. Everybody doesn’t like his stuff either” https://t.co/aT0CrspKQQ pic.twitter.com/K5l5Z4FNmB — Variety (@Variety) October 6, 2019

'Honestly, the closest I can think of them, as well made as they are, with actors doing the best they can under the circumstances, is theme parks. It isn’t the cinema of human beings trying to convey emotional, psychological experiences to another human being.'

James Gunn - who directed both Guardians Of The Galaxy films - also responded to Scorsese on Twitter as he wrote: 'Martin Scorsese is one of my 5 favorite living filmmakers.

'I was outraged when people picketed The Last Temptation of Christ without having seen the film. I’m saddened that he’s now judging my films in the same way.'

'I’m saddened that he’s now judging my films in the same way': James Gunn (pictured in June 2018) - who directed both Guardians Of The Galaxy films - also responded to Scorsese on Twitter

'I will always love Scorsese, be grateful for his contribution to cinema': Despite the comments, Gunn continued to praise The Departed director and even expressed excitement over his latest project

Despite the comments, Gunn continued to praise The Departed director and even expressed excitement over his latest project.

Gunn, 53, added: 'That said, I will always love Scorsese, be grateful for his contribution to cinema, and can’t wait to see The Irishman.'

He concluded his Twitter thread by posting: ''I'm not saying religious zealotry is the same as not liking my movies, or in the same category.'

Karen Gillan starred in both Guardians Of The Galaxy films directed by Gunn as she defended the filmmaker after Scorsese's comments.

Smash hit: Avengers: Endgame was released earlier this year as it grossed $2.796 billion worldwide making it the highest-grossing film of all-time

Gillan, 31, said of the American filmmaker to The Hollywood Reporter at the Veuve Clicquot Polo Classic in Los Angeles: "He [Gunn] injects so much of his own personality, his sense of humor...that's a very big representation of who he is as a person and therefore it's very cinematic. He's an artist.'

She also answered whether or not she fell into the same way of thinking about film as Scorsese as she said: 'I would absolutely say that Marvel movies are cinema. Cinema is storytelling with visuals.'

'He's an artist': Karen Gillan, 31, defended Gunn and Marvel films to The Hollywood Reporter at the Veuve Clicquot Polo Classic in Los Angeles

Joss Whedon - who directed the first two Avengers movies - also responded to Scorsese while also backing Gunn's filmmaking abilities.

The 55-year-old producer, director, and screenwriter wrote: 'I first think of @JamesGunn, how his heart & guts are packed into GOTG. I revere Marty, & I do see his point, but... Well there’s a reason why "I’m always angry".'

The Irishman is set for limited theatrical release on November 1 followed by digital streaming - via Netflix - on November 27.
description: The 70-year-old actor fired back at the 76-year-old filmmaker in an interview with Variety over the weekend as he lead the fellow thespians who have also starred in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
